reviews.text: I spent a night at the Bel Air with two business colleagues this week. All three of us had significant problems. We booked the hotel because the price was right, but the results were not worth it.
reviews.title: Noisy and Smelly

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The hotel is a short taxi ride from the airport and so it is a logical choice if you have an early morning flight. We noticed that the there were many flight attendants staying at the hotel, which usually means it’s cheap.
reviews.title: Very friendly staff
Take your own kettle
reviews.text: The rooms were decently decorated with new upholstery on the furniture and nice looking mirrors. However, there were missing tiles in the bathroom. (See photo.) The door to the room had two doors, one which opened in and one which opened out. It’s not clear what the second door was for, since it wouldn’t close because of the location of the security chain. (See photo.)

reviews.title: Don't trust even if you have paid already
reviews.text: When I got to my room on the parking lot side of the hotel, I noticed that the window was open, letting cool air into the room. As soon as I closed the window, an acrid odor filled my room from the bathroom. Within minutes, I realized I was smelling sewer gas. It turns out that the sink was not properly plumbed. There was no trap to prevent the escape of the sewer gas. (See photo.) I plugged the drain and the overflow on the sink and the room immediately smelled better. When I checked out, I mentioned it to the front desk staff and they said they would look into it.

I had requested a large bed because I am six feet four inches tall, and their idea of a large bed was two twin beds pushed together. This is typical in some European hotels, but was not at all comfortable. I ended up sleeping on only one of the two beds with my feet hanging off the end.
reviews.title: No air rather than Bel Air
